title: RS21424
content: In enacting the CAA of 1970, Congress differentiated between existing and new stationary sources of air pollution. Existing sources were deemed economically and technologically challenging to retrofit with new pollution control technology, while new sources were required to install state-of-the-art controls to prevent new pollution problems. The CAA of 1970 implemented different approaches for existing and new stationary sources, giving states discretion to set emission standards for existing major air pollutants. The CAA of 1970 adopted different approaches for existing and new stationary sources of air pollution. States were given discretion to set emission ceilings for existing sources, while the EPA set strict technology-based standards for new sources that may endanger public health. The 1977 amendments further expanded regulations in certain areas. The EPA sets strict technology-based standards for new sources of air pollution, known as NSPSs. These standards require the use of the best demonstrated technology to achieve emissions rates. The 1977 amendments expanded regulations for major new sources in areas with cleaner or dirtier air than national standards, requiring them to undergo NSR before construction. This process includes obtaining a pre-construction permit with emission limits based on the best available technology. The Clean Air Act requires new sources of air pollution to undergo NSR before construction, with emission limits based on best available control technology or lowest achievable emission rate. Modifications of existing sources are also subject to NSPSs and NSR. Additionally, modifications of existing sources are subject to NSPSs and NSR, with regulations defining "new source" and "modification" triggering these requirements. The definition of modification includes changes that increase the amount of any air pollutant emitted by a stationary source or result in the emission of any air pollutant not previously emitted. This definition determines which changes in a source are subject to NSPSs and NSR, focusing on increases in emissions. The EPA defines "reconstruction" as the replacement of components of an existing facility where the fixed capital cost of the new components exceeds 50 percent of the fixed capital cost to construct a new facility. This definition triggers NSPSs and NSR, similar to modifications that increase emissions. The EPA defines a "reconstruction" as the replacement of components of an existing facility where the fixed capital cost of the new components exceeds 50 percent of the fixed capital cost to construct a new facility. This definition triggers NSPSs and NSR, similar to modifications that increase emissions. In contrast with modifications, a change in a facility can constitute a reconstruction irrespective of whether it increases emissions. EPA's definition of "modification" echoes the act's definition, but also states six kinds of changes in a stationary source the Agency does not consider to be modifications. The EPA's definition of "modification" includes six exceptions for changes in a stationary source that are not considered modifications, such as maintenance, repair, and replacement (RMRR). These exceptions were developed to prevent every minor change from triggering heightened pollution-control requirements. EPA regulations did not specify the activities included as RMRR until recently. The EPA's RMRR exception allows for routine maintenance, repair, and replacement activities without triggering pollution-control requirements. Previously, eligibility for this exemption was determined through case-by-case analysis, as seen in the WEPCO case. The EPA's case-by-case approach for determining the RMRR exception was approved in the WEPCO case, where extensive renovation was proposed, triggering NSPS and PSD-area NSR requirements. EPA dismissed WEPCO's argument that the proposal qualified as RMRR. The EPA determined that WEPCO's proposal triggered NSPS and PSD-area NSR requirements, requiring a permit before construction could begin. In the WEPCO case, the Seventh Circuit ruled that the proposal went beyond RMRR due to the substantial and unprecedented extent of work on the plant. The new rule on RMRR, finalized in October 2003, allows for the replacement of components of a process unit with identical components or functional equivalents as long as the replacement cost is less than 20% of the current replacement value, does not change the unit's design parameters, and the unit continues to meet emission and operational limitations. The new per se approach is expected to reduce the use of the case-by-case approach.
